webTitle: Paul Keating still has a great turn of phrase, but his thinking is out of date | Greg Jericho

fields.bodyText: Paul Keating this week entered the economic debate like a thunderclap. Much as Shakespeare noted that “when beggars die there are no comets seen; The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes”, when great politicians argue, they deliver comets – words that light up the debate and smash opposition with a force and momentum only the best can produce. No such comets are produced by the feeble politician. It was perhaps why Malcolm Turnbull continued to disappoint throughout his prime ministership – a man so gifted with words and advocacy yet who failed to advocate and use words to inspire or explain. Instead, the slogan became his standard play and it was a standard no one really wanted to get behind. But at least it was better than the current prime minister, who has adopted such an over-the-top desperation to appear a true-blue Aussie bloke that you suspect even Chips Rafferty at his peak might have thought: “Cripes mate, you might want to tone that down a touch.” Keating has never been one to be criticised for failing to use all oratory gifts. And as Guardian Australia’s editor, Lenore Taylor, noted after watching his appearance on ABC’s 7.30 this week: “I do miss a politician who talks in words and phrases he makes up himself, not in soundbites.” The issue that brought the former prime minister into the fray this week was superannuation – and specifically a report by the Grattan Institute’s John Daley and Brendan Coates that suggested there was no need to raise the superannuation guarantee to 12.5%. The superannuation guarantee is one of Keating’s most favoured policy babies and he has always been quick to attack any suggestions it is not as vital as he regards it to be. And so he let fly, belittling the report as “recommending people retire at – work until 70, put their house in the assets test where now it isn’t. In other words you eat your house, work to 70, eat your house, and then basically find yourself at a certain point in your life where you just don’t have financial assets.” “Eat your house” is such gorgeous way to describe a situation where you borrow against the equity in your house to part-fund your retirement. It cuts to the issue – having to use the equity in your home to pay to eat. And yet gorgeous rhetoric doesn’t make Keating right. The Grattan Institute report did indeed suggest the retirement age should be raised to 70 – something I have argued against. But it pointedly suggested there needed to be consideration given to those over 60 whose health has been so impaired that it is difficult to work to be able to access the pension and superannuation earlier – in other words, not one age fits all. The other issue is that, yes, the family home has been long considered sacred and untouchable with regards to capital gains tax or assets tests for the pension. And yet, while that made sense when the average home was worth two to three years’ annual income, it is now worth about seven years’ income. That is a lot of savings being tied up essentially as a family bequest. The major problem is that fewer of us in retirement will own a house because more of us are renting than in the past. Given a great deal of our retirement policy is predicated on the belief that, by the time they retire, most people will have paid off their mortgage, as that fact changes, so too must our policy. This is why Daley and Coates argue the cost of increasing the superannuation guarantee would be better spend on areas such as rental assistance. And one key way to increase housing supply and improve the ability for people to buy a home is to encourage retirees to sell houses bought to raise a family which now are really too big for their needs. The other issue is that Keating is arguing that superannuation currently is not enough to last because people are living longer. It certainly is true that we are living longer (and is incidentally why those like Daley and Coates argue the retirement age should be lifted) but one of the more interesting findings of the Grattan Institute report is how greatly our spending needs decrease with age. They found that low-income earners in the early stages of retirement believed they missed out on experiences such as not being able to afford a holiday once a year or not being able to afford a special meal once a week due to costs – at much the same level as low-income workers – and of course they miss our much more than high-income retirees. But by the time they reach 75, both low and high-income earners have the same level of satisfaction. In effect not only do we spend less the older we get, there is less we want to spend money on. This might change as health outcomes for 75-plus year olds improve, but the reality is the percentage of 80 year olds wanting to go on a holiday around Europe is always going to be lower than that of 70 year olds. Some have argued the logical conclusion of the Grattan Institute report is to do away with compulsory super and put the money into the age pension. I’m not in that camp – I think the superannuation guarantee policy overall is good – although I believe the retail sector should be kicked out, and the tax breaks that favour high-income earners should be massively wound back. But at least it is an area of policy that gets not just excellent policy analysis, but also the words of a politician passionate about it and able to communicate in a way that grabs your attention and stimulates your brain. Pity it’s one who left office 22 years ago. • Greg writes on economics for Guardian Australia

webTitle: Productivity woes? Why giving staff an extra day off can be the answer

fields.bodyText: Lorraine Gray credits the move to a four-day working week with her company’s rapid growth. She is operations director at Pursuit Marketing, a telephone and digital marketing firm based in Glasgow, and has seen an astonishing 29.5% improvement in productivity in the two years since employees started having Fridays off, with no reduction in pay or other benefits. It has also resulted, she says, in big increases in employee satisfaction and health. Pursuit now expects projected revenues of £5m in the year to June 2019 to rise to as much as £15m in the following financial year. “This was all about creating a really motivating workplace culture,” Gray says. Call-centre companies tend to have high staff turnover – and high recruitment costs – but of Pursuit’s 130 employees, only two left last year. The company initially faced scepticism from clients, particularly “old-school” companies, but now that the four-day model has proved a success, it is planning to test it outside the UK, with new offices in the US and Málaga, southern Spain. “I’m looking forward to seeing whether this works in other countries,” Gray says. Allowing staff to work less but get the same pay sounds like a fast track to bankruptcy. Yet the counter-intuitive idea of a four-day working week is gaining momentum: shadow chancellor John McDonnell last week threw his support behind an inquiry that could one day make it Labour party policy. Like Gray, a growing number of bosses have already taken the plunge, and say they are reaping the rewards. Ankur Shah, a serial entrepreneur who founded slipper brand Mahabis in 2014, said giving workers a day off every week has had no effect on his plan to increase revenues to £20m within three years. “When I started this business,” he said, “we used [the four-day week] from the outset to allow people to focus on the work they do, not the time they spend.” Shah was one of the pioneers of the perk in the UK. He started giving staff Wednesdays off, with no pay cut, at his previous company, Techlightenment, in 2008. The advertising technology firm grew to more than 100 employees before it was bought by credit ratings agency Experian in 2011. At first, he says, the plan for a four- day week split the office, as some staff worried about a lack of structure. But once it was adopted, the reaction was almost universally positive. It has been so successful that Mahabis is now moving gradually to an “anywhere, any time” model, in which staff choose their own work model. McDonnell has asked economist Lord Skidelsky to take a thorough look at the impact on productivity of employers moving to a four-day week. Skidelsky questioned the modern urge to work longer hours (to acquire more stuff) in his 2012 book How Much is Enough?: Money and the Good Life. A long-time enthusiast for more leisure time, he argues that technology should be seen as an opportunity to free employees from the assembly line or computer screen. Reconnecting with family and community in a society that is suffering increasingly from work-related stress must be a good thing, he says. Kate Bell, head of economics at the Trades Union Congress, points out that at one time a six-day week was the norm. She cites figures from 1868, the year the TUC was founded, when a 62-hour working week was the average, compared with today’s 32-hour average – when part-time work is included. “We have these promised productivity benefits, and we wanted to think about ways workers can get a fair share of them,” she says. “If the weekend was the achievement of the 20th century, the four-day week should be our aim for the 21st century.” In a report on the future of work published earlier this year, the TUC said a four-day week for all was a realistic aim for this century. Ironically for the trade union movement, the number of hours worked by lower-paid employees has been falling over the past 20 years and it is now the better-paid staff who tend to work longer hours. A report in January by the Resolution Foundation found that in 2016 low-skilled men in full-time jobs who earned two-thirds of the average wage worked 42.2 hours a week, down from 44.3 hours in 1997. At the same time men on high pay have seen their hours rise and now work the same hours as these lower-paid counterparts. Businesses that seek to squeeze the maximum effort from their skilled and experienced staff are likely to balk at legal restrictions on hours, much as French employers have sought ways around the 35-hour week on the other side of the Channel. In response to McDonnell and the TUC, the Confederation of British Industry has criticised “rigid approaches” and policies that are “a soundbite but not a solution”. It might seem logical to ask how widget makers operating on low margins can afford to maintain pay levels while cutting staff hours. Or, likewise, how firms in highly competitive environments, where there are shortages of skilled workers and workloads are already high, could go down this route. But in fact there are no causal links between the UK’s flat productivity since the 2008 crash and particular changes in employment practices. There is as yet no statistical evidence at a national level of a link between lower hours and higher productivity. Equally, there is no evidence that longer working hours achieve better outcomes – they just lead to burnout and stress. Aidan Harper is a researcher at the Labour-linked New Economics Foundation who has campaigned for a four-day week. He says the change could have a broad range of beneficial effects, from improving gender equality to protecting mental health. “From a purely economic point of view, our current model of working is making workers sick and acting as a drag on the economy,” he says. “It’s a human catastrophe, the model of working time in this country.” Some analysts blame this on the “Uber-isation” of the workforce and a shift to low-grade transport jobs. There is little Uber drivers can do to improve their productivity: for them, a four-day week would just be a cut in income. Technology has, however, also created thousands of high-paid jobs. But with these it is difficult to measure productivity rates, especially when home life and time spent at work are difficult to separate. Linda Holbeche, an academic specialising in organisational design, says a four-day week is of little help unless a business rethinks its purpose and reviews its practices. “It would be a shame if a four-day week just frees you up to be an Uber driver. That wouldn’t be much of a victory,” she says. Rosie Warin is chief executive of Kin & Co, a communications consultancy in London which gives all its employees Wednesday afternoons off. She is planning to spread the word with a “Wednesday off-ternoon” campaign. She says: “[A four-day week is] a big step for a lot of big organisations. Having Wednesday afternoons off might be more realistic.” Labour’s big ideas The average British worker takes five days to achieve what a German worker can in four. The shadow chancellor has some radical ideas to address this gap: Universal basic income A recent poll found that 40% of British people would welcome experiments with the radical policy in their area. Finland recently tried giving €560 a month to 2,000 unemployed people aged 25 to 58, with no requirement to seek or accept employment. The scheme, however, is not being extended. Co-operatives John McDonnell’s has created a plan is for Labour councils to favour local co-operatives when choosing service providers. This has short-term costs, but supporting local employers that pay well and involve staff in decisions can bring broader benefits. Preston council has adopted the scheme. Workers on boards Under the party’s plans, companies with more than 250 staff would be legally bound to have worker directors elected by the entire workforce. The proportion of workers could be as high as a third. It goes further than most continental schemes, which involve workers in separate workers’ councils or on worker/employer boards that are subsidiary to the main board. McDonnell is also considering a plan to give workers financial shares in their company, though the complex plan put forward at Labour’s conference this year was widely criticised and is now understood to be under review. Nationalisation McDonnell is being urged to spurn traditional state ownership in favour of models that involve workers, consumers and other stakeholders. He plans to nationalise natural monopolies, such as the water industry and electricity and gas suppliers. The Co-operative party, which counts 38 Labour party MPs as members, wants the shadow finance minister to look at Welsh Water as a role model. The Welsh utility was bought with debt raised by a trust rather than the Cardiff government. It has paid off much of its borrowings, has an array of stakeholders and is highly rated by users.

webTitle: Forever in blue jeans? Levi's shakes off its troubles by embracing the past

fields.bodyText: Levi Strauss, the world’s most famous denim brand, opened a new flagship store on Friday in Times Square, New York. The 17,000 sq ft store offers on-site tailoring, a T-shirt printer and a mini-museum of the 165-year old brand. Just a few years ago Levi’s was struggling. Strangled by yoga pants and the rise of “athleisure”, and struggling to compete with cheaper jeans from fast-fashion companies like Uniqlo and H&M, the original blue jeans maker was having an identity crisis. Sales were flat and debts were piling up. But it appears to have hit its stride once more. Levi’s is reportedly considering going public, raising between $600m and $800m in a share sale that would value the company at upwards of $5bn, according to CNBC. The company’s rising fortunes have come from embracing its past while accepting the future. According to market analyst NPD, jeans sales rose 5% in the US last year and finally appear to be bouncing back after years of losses to activewear. Adding stretch materials to denim and offering many more styles has increased sales, especially to women, according to NPD. “Jeans have always offered form, fashion, and function – but now they are offering the comfort today’s consumers want,” said NPD’s Marshal Cohen in a note to clients. Stretchy jeans are a long way from Levi’s past. Levi Strauss was a Bavarian immigrant who moved to California during the gold rush of the 1840s and 50s to set up a dry goods business selling his wares to gold prospectors. One of his customers, Jacob Davis, a tailor from Nevada, had worked out how to make hard-wearing work pants by using rivets at the points of stress to make them last longer. The two patented the idea and the first pair of Levi’s was born. Levi’s went public in 1971 but the company foundered and Levi Strauss’s descendants took it private again. Today, the company is privately held by the Haas family – descendants of Levi Strauss and one of California’s most philanthropic families. The family is worth $3.7bn, according to Forbes, and owns 43% of the company’s shares. Another 200 people, mainly Haas relatives, control the majority of the remaining shares. While Levi’s is a private company, its bonds are publicly traded and it publishes quarterly reports that show why they are thinking of going public again. The company reported its fourth consecutive quarters of double-digit growth in August with sales rising in the US, Europe and Asia. Last year’s sales were close to $5bn. The renaissance has come under the stewardship of Charles “Chip” Bergh, a veteran Procter & Gamble executive who launched the Swiffer cleaning brand and used to look after Gillette. Levi’s was a brand Bergh had grown up with, he told LinkedIn earlier this year. “Here you had this incredible, iconic brand – and yet a company that had really faltered for more than a decade.” Recent woes haven’t all been about competition from other retailers. Consumers are spending less on apparel overall and more on technology and experiences. Stores like Levi’s new flagship offer consumers an experience as well as a chance to shop. They are also an opportunity for Levi’s to sell its history. “There is definitely a swing back towards authenticity,” said Bergh. “Millennials and Gen Z would rather have fewer items in their closets that are more versatile have real lasting value,” he said. Bergh said that consumers were beginning to “wise up” to the fact that fast-fashion “is just that. You buy something, it’s cheap, you wear it a few times and you throw it out.” Krista Corrigan, a retail analyst at Edited, said denim – and Levi’s – were finally emerging from the reign of Lycra. “Since September, there are 20% more jeans in stock than at this same time last year,” she said. “While menswear has remained relatively steady, women’s is a different story – up 30% over last year.” Levi’s, she noted, was being stocked significantly less at value retailers while growing its business among more fashion-forward retailers. “The success of the Levi’s brand as a whole can be partly attributed to the re-emergence of 90s nostalgia we’re seeing at the moment. There are clear indications over the years that prove denim isn’t going anywhere any time soon.”

But it appears to have hit its stride once more. Levi’s is reportedly considering going public, raising between $600m and $800m in a share sale that would value the company at upwards of $5bn, according to CNBC.

The company’s rising fortunes have come from embracing its past while accepting the future. According to market analyst NPD, jeans sales rose 5% in the US last year and finally appear to be bouncing back after years of losses to activewear.

Adding stretch materials to denim and offering many more styles has increased sales, especially to women, according to NPD. “Jeans have always offered form, fashion, and function – but now they are offering the comfort today’s consumers want,” said NPD’s Marshal Cohen in a note to clients.

Stretchy jeans are a long way from Levi’s past. Levi Strauss was a Bavarian immigrant who moved to California during the gold rush of the 1840s and 50s to set up a dry goods business selling his wares to gold prospectors. One of his customers, Jacob Davis, a tailor from Nevada, had worked out how to make hard-wearing work pants by using rivets at the points of stress to make them last longer. The two patented the idea and the first pair of Levi’s was born.

Levi’s went public in 1971 but the company foundered and Levi Strauss’s descendants took it private again. Today, the company is privately held by the Haas family – descendants of Levi Strauss and one of California’s most philanthropic families.

The family is worth $3.7bn, according to Forbes, and owns 43% of the company’s shares. Another 200 people, mainly Haas relatives, control the majority of the remaining shares.

While Levi’s is a private company, its bonds are publicly traded and it publishes quarterly reports that show why they are thinking of going public again. The company reported its fourth consecutive quarters of double-digit growth in August with sales rising in the US, Europe and Asia. Last year’s sales were close to $5bn.

The renaissance has come under the stewardship of Charles “Chip” Bergh, a veteran Procter & Gamble executive who launched the Swiffer cleaning brand and used to look after Gillette.

Levi’s was a brand Bergh had grown up with, he told LinkedIn earlier this year. “Here you had this incredible, iconic brand – and yet a company that had really faltered for more than a decade.”

Recent woes haven’t all been about competition from other retailers. Consumers are spending less on apparel overall and more on technology and experiences. Stores like Levi’s new flagship offer consumers an experience as well as a chance to shop. They are also an opportunity for Levi’s to sell its history.

“There is definitely a swing back towards authenticity,” said Bergh. “Millennials and Gen Z would rather have fewer items in their closets that are more versatile have real lasting value,” he said. Bergh said that consumers were beginning to “wise up” to the fact that fast-fashion “is just that. You buy something, it’s cheap, you wear it a few times and you throw it out.”

Krista Corrigan, a retail analyst at Edited, said denim – and Levi’s – were finally emerging from the reign of Lycra. “Since September, there are 20% more jeans in stock than at this same time last year,” she said. “While menswear has remained relatively steady, women’s is a different story – up 30% over last year.”

Levi’s, she noted, was being stocked significantly less at value retailers while growing its business among more fashion-forward retailers. “The success of the Levi’s brand as a whole can be partly attributed to the re-emergence of 90s nostalgia we’re seeing at the moment. There are clear indications over the years that prove denim isn’t going anywhere any time soon.”
fields.trailText: The 165-year-old denim brand had faded – but it seems to have hit its stride once more, and is reportedly considering going public

webTitle: Bug grub: Sainsbury's to stock edible insects on shelves in a UK first

fields.bodyText: Barbecued bugs are are going on the shelves of British supermarkets as Sainsbury’s becomes the first big UK grocer to stock edible insects. The retailer will start selling roasted crickets – described as “crunchy in texture with a rich smoky flavour” – in 250 of its stores from Monday, capitalising on the growing prominence of bush tucker in the global warming debate. The damaging environmental impact of global meat production has spurred interest in bugs – which can be bred in significant numbers without taking up large amounts of land, water or feed – as an alternative, sustainable food source. The packaging for the crunchy crickets, made by London-based Eat Grub, deploys the environmental argument in a bid to win over shoppers who might balk at bugs for lunch. The new product is trumpeted by its manufacturer as “more sustainable than pork scratchings … and more exciting than a crisp”. The Eat Grub bugs – acheta domesticus, or house crickets – are farmed in Europe and come in packets of about 50, at £1.50 per bag. If shoppers can get over the ick factor, they can consume the crickets as a snack or as a garnish for noodles, soups and salads. The global edible insect market is set to exceed $520m (£406m) by 2023, according to recent research. The UN Food and Agriculture Organization says at least 2 billion people regularly consume insects, and the tiny creatures could also help meet the food needs of the world’s growing population. More than 1,000 insect species are eaten around the world but hardly feature in the diets of many rich nations. In the UK, crickets and other insects have so far been predominantly limited to quirky pop-ups or sales through online outlets, while they also feature on a few restaurant menus. The move by Sainsbury’s means this is the first time consumers will be able to buy insects from a supermarket. “Insect snacks should no longer be seen as a gimmick or something for a dare,” said Rachel Eyre, head of future brands at Sainsbury’s. “It’s clear that consumers are increasingly keen to explore this new sustainable protein source.” Insects are naturally very low in calories and suitable for gluten- and dairy-free diets, as well as being exceptionally high in protein. Gram for gram, dried crickets contain more protein than beef, chicken and pork – with 100g containing 68g of protein, compared with only 31g of protein in beef. The food group also tops the list when it comes to sustainability. Bugs emit considerably lower levels of greenhouse gases than most livestock and are more efficient in terms of the resources needed to farm them – crickets, for example, need 12 times less feed than cattle. “As the population increases, we urgently need to look at alternative protein sources to make the most of land available for food production,” the food policy manager at WWF UK, Duncan Williamson, said. “Insects are incredibly sustainable and can help to reduce our carbon footprint.” Other retailers are capitalising on the rise of insect food. The online grocer Ocado sells Eat Grub’s protein bars made of cricket powder, while the French supermarket group Carrefour has started selling bug-based products from the Jimini’s range in more than 300 of its branches in Spain. The products include spicy chilli buffalo worms and insect-based energy bars, pasta and granola. The UK department store Selfridges, which also sells some of Jimini’s products, will next February launch a pop-up “Bug Bar” selling a range of products including cricket flour while introducing shoppers to new recipes. The specialist food shops Fortnum & Mason and Planet Organic also stock the Jimini’s range. Chefs report some success in encouraging their diners to tuck into creepy-crawlies. Archipelago restaurant in central London has cricket and locusts on its menu, bought in bulk frozen from a supplier on the Isle of Wight. Diners at Heston Blumenthal’s Michelin-starred Fat Duck restaurant can savour mealworms from the Netherlands in edible soil in a savoury “woodlands-themed” dish – part of its £325 tasting menu. Taste test: bitter with a spicy kick’ “I’m fully behind the idea of eating insects, but this one still feels like a work in progress. For one, the cricket looks too much like a cricket – I can make out its thorax and abdomen and I’d rather I couldn’t. They taste of whatever they are flavoured with – bitter with a little spicy kick at the end – rather than the cricket itself, which is perhaps a mixed blessing. But for me the sticking point is the texture. Crisp on the outside, it quickly yields before popping in your mouth. All that aside, if I didn’t know this was a cricket I could well imagine taking a handful out of a bowl at a party without thinking twice. But since I do, I can’t really get past it.” Morwenna Ferrier “I often have a little protein snack to keep me going in the afternoon – nuts or seeds or something boring like that – and crickets felt like they could definitely liven up that arena. They were satisfyingly crispy with an overall nutty flavour. There was also some sweetness and a hefty hit of coriander seed, although I suspect they were flavourings that had been added rather than the cricket itself. Despite the horrified looks of my colleagues, I’d recommend them – they tasted different without being off-puttingly weird. They did look like animal droppings, however, which is even worse than looking like crickets.” Tim Jonze
